newsitem.title: BRAZIL: FOCUS-Brazil ends meet in chill of debt warnings.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Brazil ends meet in chill of debt warnings.

text.p: Brazil Thursday ended its first-ever international seminar on public finances with the unsettling ring of debt warnings from international economic luminaries hanging in the air.

Finance Minister Pedro Malan took heed of the doom-and-gloom merchants and acknowledged that the great challenge Brazil faced in the future was consolidating its "Plano Real" economic stabilization plan and modernizing the state.
"There's a lot that remains to be done," he said.
The grim tone was set by the International Monetary Fund's director of fiscal affairs, Vitor Tanzi.

He said Monday Brazil's current interest rate levels combined with annual economic growth of 3.0-4.0 percent and a primary budget surplus of only 1.0 percent of gross domestic product would cause substantial growth in debt.
Tanzi added that the results of an IMF study on Brazil's total debt were "worrisome", without going into details.
Brazil's net public sector debt in June stood at 33.9 percent of GDP, with net internal debt of 210.7 billion reais reaching 29.6 percent of GDP.
The IMF words of warning were echoed by Ricardo Hausmann, chief economist at the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB).
"We would like to see Brazil accumulate debt at a much lower speed than it is currently doing," Hausmann told Reuters.
Brazilian officials, while acknowledging all was not well, played down their comments.
Francisco Lopes, monetary policy director of the Central Bank, told reporters Brazil had to increase its primary surplus to stop its debt stockpile from growing.
But he dismissed as "exaggerated" suggestions a surplus of 3.0-4.0 percent was needed to prevent "a debt explosion".
Lopes said Brazil only needed a primary budget surplus of 1.5 percent of GDP to halt debt growth in its tracks.

He added that commentators on Brazil's debt had to take account of one-off distortions, like federal Banco do Brasil's 7.8 billion real first half 1996 loss and plans to securitize a $50 billion black hole in the federal FCVS housing fund.
The four-day seminar, held to mark the 10th anniversary of the creation of the National Treasury Secretariat, ended as it began -- with mutual backslapping by Brazilian officials.
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso took the opportunity Monday to play domestic politics, eloquently praising arch-foe and former president Jose Sarney for having set up the Treasury.
A beaming Sarney responded with some self-congratulation.
"When you drink from a well, it is good to remember who built it," he said, quoting what he said was a Chinese proverb.
It was left to Malan, regarded in Brasilia as a pragmatist technician and not the smoothest political operator, to bring up the subject at hand -- public finances.

"Everything Tanzi said is part of what we talk about everyday in the government. There is nothing in his text that I disagree with. In fact, we have a great convergence of views on what is happening in Brazil," he said at the opening ceremony.
-- Brasilia newsroom 55-61-2230358
